thread.title: Marines shared photos of naked female recruits on secret Facebook page: report
thread.title_full: Marines shared photos of naked female recruits on secret Facebook page: report | New York Post

author: Chris Perez
title: Marines shared photos of naked female recruits on secret Facebook page: report
text:
Hundreds of US Marines swapped naked pictures of female recruits and veterans on a secret Facebook page — many of whom had no idea that they had been photographed, a report says.
The images were shared on a page titled “Marines United” and posted by active-duty and retired members of the Marine Corps, Navy Corpsman and British Royal Marines, according to the Center for Investigative Reporting.
More than two dozen women — including active duty and enlisted service members — were spotlighted on the social media site and identified by their full name, rank and military duty station, CIR reported on it’s website Reveal .
One woman, a corporal pictured in uniform, had been followed at Camp Lejeune in North Carolina by a fellow Marine and secretly photographed while she wasn’t looking, the center said.
After her photo was posted to the Marines United page on Feb. 16, crude comments reportedly poured in.
“Take her out back and pound her out,” one Facebook user wrote. “Video it though… for science.”
Senior officials at Headquarters Marine Corps have verified that incident, as well as the photographs of the other active duty members and veterans, according to CIR.
The Defense Department is reportedly investigating hundreds of Marines who posted on the Marines United page, which was first uncovered by a nonprofit news organization called The War Horse.
The outlet is run by Marine veteran and Purple Heart recipient Thomas Brennan. He contacted the Marine Corps on Jan. 30 after discovering the pictures — and more than 2,500 comments that accompanied them. Less than a day later, the accounts responsible for sharing the sexually explicit images were deleted and the page was gone, CIR reported.
The Marines who shared the photos are said the be stationed at bases across the globe, from Japan to North Carolina. Many of them targeted Brennan on Facebook after he ousted the Marines United page.
“Waterboard this p-o-s,” wrote one user. “I’ll pay 500 to the dude that can get good nudes of his girl.”
It’s unclear how many Marines are being probed over the Facebook page.
If proven to have posted an explicit photo of another person, an enlisted service member could be charged with violations of the Uniform Code of Military Justice, according to CIR.
A Marine who directly participates in, encourages or condones these actions may also face charges or adverse administrative actions.
Top brass in the Marine Corps condemned the soldier’s actions on Sunday, saying there was no place for it in the service.
“There is no place for this type of demeaning or degrading behavior in our Corps,” Sergeant Major Ronald L. Green, 18th Sergeant Major, told CBS News .
“Let me be perfectly clear; no person should be treated this way,” he said. “It is inconsistent with our Core Values, and it impedes our ability to perform our mission.”
